Session 3 â€“ Expressing Change with Clarity: Writing and Speaking in the Workplace

Introduction

In todayâ€™s workplace, understanding changes isnâ€™t enoughâ€”you must communicate them clearly and professionally. Whether explaining new procedures, outlining plans, or guiding colleagues, your communication shapes workplace success.

In this session, youâ€™ll apply practical skills to:

  • Use appropriate future forms (decision, plan, schedule, or prediction) based on intent.
  • Write concise, effective internal messages to inform or guide others.
  • Deliver clear, polite spoken explanations about workplace tools or routines.

Youâ€™ll refine grammar, vocabulary, structure, and tone through two realistic tasksâ€”one written and one oralâ€”connecting language to real-world communication. Get ready to make your English accurate, helpful, and workplace-ready!

âœ¨ Hone your skills to communicate workplace changes with confidence and clarity!

Use of English â€“ Mastering the Future in Context

Introduction

This session consolidates your understanding of future forms in Englishâ€”will, going to, present continuous, and present simpleâ€”enabling you to use them confidently in workplace contexts. Each form serves a distinct purpose, such as expressing a spontaneous decision, a personal plan, a fixed appointment, an official schedule, or a prediction based on opinion or evidence.

This section will help you:

  • Clarify the differences between future forms.
  • Select the appropriate form for specific situations.
  • Practice with realistic workplace examples.

Youâ€™ll begin with a diagnostic test to assess your current knowledge, review key concepts in a grammar focus, and then apply future forms through exercises that prepare you for writing and speaking tasks. Get ready to express future events with clarity, accuracy, and purpose!

âœ¨ Refine your grammar to communicate future plans and predictions with confidence in the workplace!

Get Ready to Check Your Grammar!

Before diving into practical tasks, letâ€™s assess your confidence with future forms in English. This diagnostic test will help you check your understanding of will, going to, present continuous, and present simple when talking about the future. Itâ€™s not about gradesâ€”itâ€™s about discovering your strengths and what you might need to review.

This test focuses on:

  • will â€“ for spontaneous decisions and opinion-based predictions

Talking about the Future: Will, Going to, and Present Continuous

Introduction

When talking about the future in English, you choose different forms based on what you want to expressâ€”whether itâ€™s a quick decision, a plan, or something already set. The forms will, going to, and present continuous help you share your thoughts about the future in a way that feels natural and clear. This section explains how to use these forms in workplace situations, so you can communicate with confidence.
ðŸŽ§ Complementary Audio â€“ Guided Explanation
This audio supports you as you go through the lesson. Listen to it for a step-by-step explanation with spoken examples. Itâ€™s especially helpful if you prefer learning by listening or want to review while doing other tasks.

1. Will: Quick Decisions and Personal Thoughts

Use will when:

  • Quick decisions (you decide right now):
    Example: â€œOh, you dropped your pen! Iâ€™ll get it for you.â€
    Example: â€œIâ€™m tired. I think Iâ€™ll go to bed.â€
  • Guesses about the future (what you think or believe):
    Example: â€œI think itâ€™ll rain tomorrow.â€
    Example: â€œHe will probably be late.â€

Why it works: Will shows that youâ€™re thinking about the future in the moment. Itâ€™s like picturing something new in your mind, either a decision you just made or an idea about what might happen, without needing proof.

ðŸ’¡ WillÂ is great for instant choices or sharing your thoughts about the future.

2. Going to: Plans and Things You See Coming

Use going to when:

  • Plans you already made (you decided earlier):
    Example: â€œIâ€™m going to start a new course next week.â€
    Example: â€œWeâ€™re going to visit our grandmother this weekend.â€
  • Guesses based on clues (you see or know something now):
    Example: â€œLook at those dark clouds â€” itâ€™s going to rain.â€
    Example: â€œWatch out! Youâ€™re going to fall!â€

Why it works: Going to connects the future to whatâ€™s happening now. Itâ€™s like looking at a path youâ€™re already onâ€”either a plan youâ€™ve set or something you can see is about to happen because of clear signs.

ðŸ’¡ Going toÂ is perfect for plans or when you notice something that makes the future obvious.

3. Present Continuous: Fixed Plans

Use present continuous when:

  • Definite plans (arrangements already set, often with others):
    Example: â€œIâ€™m meeting Sarah at 3 p.m.â€
    Example: â€œWeâ€™re flying to Paris on Monday.â€

Why it works: Present continuous makes the future feel like itâ€™s already happening. Itâ€™s as if the plan is so certainâ€”like itâ€™s written in your calendarâ€”that it feels real and fixed right now.

ðŸ’¡ Present continuousÂ shows plans that are confirmed and ready to go.

Summary Table

Form Use forâ€¦ Example
will ðŸ’¬ Quick decision
ðŸ’­ Guess (based on thoughts)		 â€œIâ€™ll answer the phone.â€
â€œSheâ€™ll love this film.â€
going to ðŸ“… Plan
ðŸ” Guess (based on clues)		 â€œIâ€™m going to join the gym.â€
â€œItâ€™s going to snow â€“ look at the sky!â€
present continuous ðŸ“† Definite plan â€œWeâ€™re having dinner with them tomorrow.â€

Common Mistakes to Avoid

  • Incorrect: â€œI think itâ€™s going to rain tomorrow.â€ (Just a thought, no clues)
    Correct: â€œI think it will rain tomorrow.â€
  • Incorrect: â€œIâ€™ll visit grandma this weekend.â€ (If you planned it already)
    Correct: â€œIâ€™m going to visit grandma this weekend.â€

Why these mistakes happen: Choosing the wrong form can mix up how you picture the future. Use will for thoughts or instant decisions, going to for plans or clear signs, and present continuous for set arrangements to match what you mean.

âœ¨ Practice these forms to talk about the future clearly and confidently in the workplace!

Use will for spontaneous decisions or predictions without evidence, going to for plans or predictions with evidence, and present continuous for fixed arrangements with a scheduled time.

Writing â€“ Communicating Clearly and Professionally

Introduction

Effective professional writing is about clarity, politeness, and organization, not complexity. This section teaches you to write concise internal messagesâ€”such as emails, notes, or announcementsâ€”to inform your team about changes, events, or new colleagues in a workplace setting.

You will:

  • Explore strategies to plan and structure your writing.
  • Practice using future forms to describe plans, arrangements, and updates.
  • Learn useful expressions for polite, clear, and effective communication.

These skills will boost your confidence in real-world writing scenarios and prepare you for the writing tasks in this unit. Letâ€™s get started!

âœ¨ Craft clear and professional messages to shine in any workplace!

Writing Lesson â€“ Crafting Short Professional Messages

Why This Matters

Clear and polite internal messages are key to saving time and boosting collaboration in the workplace. Whether youâ€™re announcing a change or welcoming a new colleague, your words influence how others respond. This lesson equips you to write concise, professional messages that achieve results.

CEFR-Based Strategies ðŸŽ“

This lesson targets CEFR B1â€“B2 level writing skills for effective internal messages. Youâ€™ll develop these strategies:

CEFR Strategy What It Means
Planning and Compensation ðŸ§  Organize your ideas before writing for clarity.
Considering the Reader ðŸ‘€ Use a polite tone suited to your audience.
Using Formulaic Language ðŸ§© Incorporate common phrases to sound natural.

Strategy: Plan â€“ Write â€“ Review ðŸ§­

Follow this three-step process to create effective messages:

Step 1: Plan Your Message ðŸ“Œ

Before writing, answer:

  • Whatâ€™s the message about? (e.g., a change, reminder, welcome)
  • Whoâ€™s the audience? (e.g., team, department, new colleague)
  • What should they know or do? (e.g., attend, confirm, prepare)

This keeps your message focused.

Step 2: Write with Structure ðŸ“Œ

Use this 3-part structure for clarity:

  • Opening ðŸ”¹ (1â€“2 sentences): State the purpose.
    Example: â€œIâ€™m writing to share an update on our project timeline.â€
    Example: â€œWeâ€™re excited to welcome a new team member.â€
  • Main Information ðŸ”¹ (2â€“4 sentences): Provide key details (What? When? Who? Where? Why? Action needed?).
    Example: â€œThe new software launches Monday at 10:00 a.m. All staff must attend a 30-minute training session. IT will handle setup remotely.â€
  • Closing ðŸ”¹ (1 sentence): End politely, offer support.
    Example: â€œPlease reach out with any questions.â€
    Example: â€œThanks for your cooperation!â€

Step 3: Use Formulaic Expressions ðŸ“Œ

These phrases make your message professional and natural:

Purpose Expressions
To Inform Iâ€™m writing to inform youâ€¦ / This is to update youâ€¦
To Announce Weâ€™re pleased to announceâ€¦ / There will beâ€¦
To Request Please ensure youâ€¦ / You are invited toâ€¦
To Close Thank you for your attention. / Contact me if needed.

Grammar Focus: Future Forms ðŸ§ 

Use the right future form to describe plans and schedules:

Form Use Example
will Announcements, decisions The meeting will start at 9:00 a.m.
going to Planned actions Weâ€™re going to roll out new guidelines.
present continuous Fixed arrangements Weâ€™re training staff on Thursday.
present simple Timetables, schedules The office closes at 5:00 p.m.

Model Text ðŸ§¾

Subject: Team Training Session Next Week

Dear Team,

Iâ€™m writing to inform you about a mandatory training session.

It will take place on Wednesday at 2:00 p.m. in the main conference room. Weâ€™re covering the new project management tool, and everyone needs to attend. Please bring your laptop.

Let me know if you have any questions.

Best regards,
[Your Name]

Checklist for Success

A great internal message:

  • States the purpose clearly
  • Includes brief, complete details
  • Follows a logical structure
  • Uses future forms correctly
  • Maintains a polite, professional tone
  • Is free of grammar or spelling errors

CEFR Alignment ðŸ“˜

This lesson aligns with CEFR B1â€“B2 descriptors:

  • Write short, connected texts on familiar topics.
  • Adapt language to the audience with polite expressions.
  • Communicate information concisely in routine contexts.

Get Writing! âœï¸

Youâ€™ll now complete:

  • A guided practice task to apply the structure.
  • An evaluated task to write an independent message.
âœ¨ Letâ€™s craft messages that inform and inspire action!

Practice Task â€“ Writing a Welcome Message

Task Details

  • ðŸ“Œ Task Type: Guided writing â€“ Informative message
  • ðŸ“Œ Submission Format: Post your text in the forum for Unit 3 â€“ Writing Practice

Task Instructions

You are part of a small team in your company. A new colleague is joining next week. Write a short internal message to:

  • Inform your coworkers about this new colleague.
  • Share basic details (name, position, start date, location, etc.).
  • Ask your colleagues to support them during their first days.

Use the structure and expressions from the writing lesson.

Objectives ðŸŽ¯

Your message should:

  • Include a short introduction stating the purpose.
  • Describe who the new colleague is and when they start.
  • Include a polite closing.
  • Use at least two future forms (will, going to, present continuous, present simple).

Example Opening ðŸ“˜

Iâ€™m writing to let you know that a new colleague will join our department next week. Her name is Laura, and sheâ€™s going to support the customer service team.

Submission Details

  • âœï¸ Length: 80â€“100 words
  • Post: Submit your message as a reply in the forum titled â€œUNIT 3 â€“ WRITING PRACTICEâ€.
  • Engage: Read at least one classmateâ€™s message and leave a short, supportive comment.

Optional Reflection

After posting, think about:

  • Did I include all the necessary information?
  • Did I use the correct tone and a clear structure?
  • Did I apply the future forms accurately?
âœ¨ Write a welcoming message that sets a positive tone for your new colleagueâ€™s arrival!

Speaking â€“ Explaining Tasks and Tools with Confidence

Introduction

In the workplace, speaking clearly is about guiding others with confidence, especially when explaining tasks or tools. This section teaches you to deliver short, effective explanations for routine procedures, like training a new colleague or demonstrating a system. These skills are vital for collaboration and leadership.

You will:

  • Master strategies to structure clear, logical explanations.
  • Practice future forms to describe outcomes and plans.
  • Use polite and professional language to support and engage listeners.

Get ready to speak with ease and make a real impactâ€”your voice matters! Letâ€™s dive in!

âœ¨ Build your speaking skills to guide others with clarity and confidence in the workplace!

Speaking Lesson â€“ Explaining Tasks and Tools at Work

Why This Lesson?

Explaining how to use tools or complete tasks is a vital workplace skill, especially when training new colleagues. This lesson helps you deliver clear, confident explanations to make collaboration and training seamless.

CEFR-Based Strategies ðŸŽ“

At CEFR B1â€“B2, effective speakers use these strategies:

CEFR Strategy What It Means
Planning Structure your explanation logically.
Compensating Use simple words if technical terms are unknown.
Monitoring and Repair Check listener understanding and adjust as needed.

Strategy: Explain â€“ Structure â€“ Support ðŸ§­

Follow this three-step approach:

Step 1: Clear Introduction

State what youâ€™re explaining and why:

  • â€œIâ€™ll show you how this tool works.â€
  • â€œLetâ€™s go over how to file a report.â€
  • â€œThis system manages deliveries â€” hereâ€™s how to use it.â€

Step 2: Structured Explanation

Use clear sequencing:

  • First, you need toâ€¦
  • Then / Next, â€¦
  • After that, â€¦
  • Finally, â€¦

Add emphasis where needed:

  • â€œItâ€™s important toâ€¦â€
  • â€œMake sure youâ€¦â€
  • â€œIf something goes wrong, â€¦â€

Step 3: Support and Check

Close with polite, supportive phrases:

  • â€œIs anything unclear?â€
  • â€œWant me to go over that again?â€
  • â€œYouâ€™ll pick it up quickly!â€

Useful Phrases and Grammar ðŸ§ 

Functional Phrases

Purpose Expressions
Introduce Iâ€™d like to show youâ€¦ / This is used toâ€¦
Start Letâ€™s begin withâ€¦ / First, you need toâ€¦
Instruct Click here. / Enter this field.
Emphasize Be careful toâ€¦ / Donâ€™t forget toâ€¦
Invite Questions Ready to try? / Need me to repeat?

Grammar

  • Future Forms: Describe outcomes.
    Examples: â€œSubmit the form, and itâ€™ll generate a code.â€ / â€œThis is going to streamline our process.â€
  • Imperatives: Give clear instructions.
    Examples: â€œLog in with your ID.â€ / â€œSelect the correct option.â€
  • Vocabulary: Use field-specific terms (e.g., platform, module, report, access code).

Example Dialogue ðŸ§¾

You: Hi, welcome aboard! Iâ€™ll show you how to log an issue in our system. First, open the support platform and click â€œNew Ticket.â€ Next, add a title, pick a category, and write a brief description. Finally, hit â€œSubmitâ€ â€” youâ€™ll get a confirmation email. Any questions? Iâ€™m here to help!

CEFR Goals

By the end, you should:

  • Give clear instructions for familiar tasks.
  • Explain processes using simple connectors.
  • Adapt your speech based on listener reactions.

Speaking Tips ðŸ’¡

  • Speak slowly and clearly.
  • Use short, simple sentences.
  • Point or gesture if explaining in person.
  • If stuck on a word, describe it (e.g., â€œthe tool forâ€¦â€).
  • Smile â€” your tone sets the mood!
âœ¨ Master clear explanations to guide colleagues with confidence!

Speaking Practice Task â€“ Explain a Simple Workplace Procedure

Submission Details

  • Format: Record your voice (audio or video) and upload it in the forum titled â€œUNIT 3 â€“ SPEAKING PRACTICEâ€.

Context

Imagine a new colleague has just joined your company. They need help with a simple, routine procedureâ€”something you do often and know well. You will give them a short, friendly explanation of how to do it.

Task Selection ðŸ’¡

Choose one of these everyday tasks (or a similar one from your field):

  • How to log into a shared platform or system
  • How to request a day off or report an absence
  • How to use a digital form (e.g., inventory, delivery, incident)
  • How to book a meeting room
  • How to clock in / out
  • How to label and store materials or products

Objectives ðŸŽ¯

Your explanation should:

  • Start with a short introduction (â€œLet me show you how toâ€¦â€).
  • Include at least 3 clear steps, using sequencing language (Firstâ€¦ Thenâ€¦ Finallyâ€¦).
  • Use imperatives and workplace vocabulary.
  • Mention at least one thing that will happen after completing the task (use a future form).
  • End with a polite closing (â€œLet me know if you need help.â€).

Useful Structure ðŸ“˜

Hi, welcome!

Iâ€™ll explain how to ___________________.

First, you need to ___________________.

Then, ___________________.

After that, ___________________.

Once you finish, ___________________ (use a future form here).

Let me know if anythingâ€™s unclear!

Duration ðŸ•’

  • Length: 1â€“2 minutes
  • Style: Use natural speech. You donâ€™t need to memorizeâ€”just sound clear and helpful.

Optional Reflection ðŸ§ 

After recording your explanation, ask yourself:

  • Was my message clear and easy to follow?
  • Did I organize the steps logically?
  • Did I use a future form to describe what happens next?
âœ¨ Record a clear and friendly explanation to help your new colleague succeed!
